args: Does this describe a specific, new, official action or formal announcement already taken/made by the Trump administration? Answer only "yes" or "no". After under-the-radar retool, D.C. United hopes to ‘prove people wrong’ D.C. United spent the offseason acquiring more than a dozen players, accounting for about half the roster. The goalkeeping corps is new. An Aussie center back arrived from Scotland, a Brazilian winger via Poland. Five newcomers are expected to start Saturday night’s opener against Toronto FC at Audi Field. Why, then, does it feel as if United did not accomplish much this winter? Perhaps because, unlike many teams around MLS, United did not make any blockbuster trades or sign a high-priced international player. Instead, it acquired three players who missed most of last season with injuries and four who toiled most, if not all, of 2024 in the second division. Two other acquisitions were MLS backups. Three came from overseas with modest fanfare, another through the college draft. “For those that have that perception, that’s understandable,” United Coach Troy Lesesne said of the restrained activity. “We’ve signed some players that may not carry that type of [big] name but are very talented themselves. They fit our game model, and we believe in them, and we hope that D.C. United is going to be a platform for them to take off in their career.” United has one of MLS’s biggest names: captain Christian Benteke, MLS’s scoring champion. He is D.C.’s only designated player — the label for talent that exceeds salary cap restrictions and requires ownership to pay mostly out of pocket. Each team is allowed to employ up to three DPs. United’s second slot remains filled by team assists leader Mateusz Klich, even though he is no longer on the roster. Though he was traded to Atlanta, most of his contract remains on United’s books. Although Lesesne and his players are upbeat, United failed to generate any offseason buzz in MLS circles. Accordingly, preseason predictions have D.C. missing the playoffs for the sixth consecutive year and finishing at or near the bottom of the 15-team Eastern Conference. “You want to be the team that’s looked at as the big dogs in the league. You want to be one of the favorites and have that privilege of having the target on your back,” all-star right back Aaron Herrera said. “But at the same time, we’re realistic with ourselves. We saw what we did last year and where we ended up. So how do we expect to be [higher in] anyone’s prediction? We’re here to prove people wrong.” Since Lesense and General Manager Ally Mackay took over before the 2024 season, the roster has been gutted. Benteke and injured midfielder Jackson Hopkins are the only players remaining from the 2023 opener. This year’s squad features not only 13 newcomers but four holdovers who either arrived deep into last season or missed most of the year with injury. Returning center back Lucas Bartlett has a new partner: Australia’s Kye Rowles, a 2022 World Cup starter who played the past 2½ years for Hearts in Scotland. The new starting goalkeeper is Kim Joon Hong, a 21-year-old South Korean. Hosei Kijima, a rookie midfielder for St. Louis City last year, drew rave reviews from teammates in the preseason. Costa Rican Randall Leal (Nashville) and Brazilian João Peglow (Polish league) also hope to bolster the attack. Brazilian playmaker Gabriel Pirani, in his second full season in Washington, is aiming for a breakout year after showing bright signs late last season. Lesesne will also need players to show improvement after mixed performances last year. “When I look at myself, I’m not saying I wasted a year, but as a young player, every year you want to take big steps forward,” said Matti Peltola, a 22-year-old midfielder. “If I’m not going to be able to take big steps forward this year, then I’m really looking [in] the mirror, big time.” With some roster space and cap flexibility, United could continue to make changes until the initial roster deadline April 23. The summer transfer window, which opens in July, typically offers an abundant international marketplace. “We created a good group,” Benteke said. “Even though I’m the captain [and] I’m the leader, I believe the star of the team is going to be the group because the way we want to play, we will need all of us.” Lesesne has retained a high-pressure style designed to force turnovers and create immediate opportunities. In the preseason, he implemented a plan that also won’t rely as heavily on Benteke (23 goals) and will generate a wider variety of chances. “It’s in constant evolution and improvement,” Lesesne said. “If you watched us in preseason, you could see, ‘Okay, they’re trying to go for something a little bit different.’” Defensively, United will need to tighten up not only in its own end but in transition. Last year, teams often unlocked D.C.’s press and capitalized on open space. United conceded 70 goals, third most in MLS and second most in club history. “The intensity of the press is still going to be the same,” Herrera said. “But there’s a couple different pieces, couple different moving parts.” United will also need to improve its home performance after ending 2024 in a 1-6-5 rut at Audi Field and 4-8-5 overall. The team will play three of its first four matches at Buzzard Point, and none of those four opponents had a winning record last year. While championship aspirations seem far-fetched, Lesesne and the players say they see promise after narrowly missing the playoffs last fall. (The front office also sees promise: To entice former season ticket holders to return, United promised a 30 percent rebate if the team fails to make the playoffs.) “We were competitive last year, and we started to show ourselves in terms of the proof of concept was there,” Lesesne said. “We want to build on that, but we have to take a bigger step this year. I don’t want to be around this position of nine, 10, 11 [in the standings] and just be in the mix. I’d like us to take a step forward.” D.C. United roster
result: No - this article is about D.C. United's soccer team and their roster changes for the upcoming season. It has nothing to do with any actions or announcements by the Trump administration.
